awd_titl_txt: CSR:Small: High Data Density Short Range Wireless Telemetry for Next Generation IoT Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
High Data Density Short Range Wireless Telemetry for Next Generation Internet-of-Things (IoT) Applications (SWiT-IoT)

The long-term goal of this SWiT-IoT project is to establish a transformative and multidisciplinary research and innovation on high data-density short-range wireless telemetry and energy-efficient computational platform integrated with custom analog radio-frequency (analog-RF) circuit and system architectures for Internet-of-Things (IoT) applications. Proliferation of wireless sensors and sensor network has enabled widespread deployment of multi-sensors for IoT applications. With the increase of wireless sensors, the cumulative data volume from a large group of sensors is creating bottleneck for real-time data processing and data transmission through a limited wireless spectrum. To alleviate these problems, the SWiT-IoT research project is going to investigate a two-phase approach. On the first phase, the project will investigate a local processing or computational unit for in-situ low-level signal processing, data reduction, and enable high volume of data communication within the specified bandwidth. On the second phase, the project will investigate a novel pulse encoding scheme using orthogonal pulses to compress the data volume further. This two-fold data reduction (local processing and pulse encoding) enables high data-rate support within the specified bandwidth. The compressed data stream will then be fed to an injection-locked power oscillator to drive the antenna for wireless transmission. The proposed transformative large volume wireless data acquisition scheme will influence various sensor related applications and decision-making processes, such as transportation, public health, cortical mapping, smart homes, etc. The education goal is to integrate the artistic skills of underrepresented K-12 students to motivate, engage and help learning STEM materials through a fun loving environment and get them prepared for future STEM careers. The project will continue training undergraduate and graduate students, conduct summer camps, and promote outreach programs through "It's Electric", "C3-STEM" and UAB CORD program, to increase the number of underrepresented and minorities towards higher education.

In pursue of the research objectives in the SWiT-IoT project, mainly three research goals are targeted: (i) Energy-Efficient Local Processing for Data Reduction, (ii) An energy-efficient analog-RF chip level implementation of multi-order orthogonal pulse generator, and (iii) Spectral efficient orthogonal pulse based analog pulse-sequence encoding. First, a local processing unit will be investigated by employing oscillatory neural network (ONN) and improved spike detector algorithms. By utilizing ultra-low-power self-oscillating nodes, the ONN will perform class-associative pattern recognition task by synchrony or desynchrony among the nodes, and only relay the values of the recognition indicators frequency of synchronization and convergence time, instead of the raw data. A modified nonlinear energy operator based energy-efficient spike detector algorithm will be investigated for detecting signal events e.g. impact loading, action potentials, abrupt changes, etc. and relay the event stamp to reduce the data volume. Second, the SWiT-IoT project will investigate a Modified Hermite Polynomial based multi-order orthogonal pulse generation scheme. An innovative neuro-inspired architecture will be utilized with reduced system complexity, better energy-efficiency, and integrated circuit level implementation with smaller form factor. Third, a novel combinatorial pulse-sequence encoding will allow simultaneous multichannel wireless telemetry with superb spectrum-efficient data density and data security. In this scheme, n distinct multi-order orthogonal pulses will be used to create pulse-sequence for each channel. The use of (n-1) redundant orthogonal pulses for each channel will enable supporting a large number (= n!) of channels and (n-1)!-times of data rate improvement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the increase of wireless sensors, the cumulative data volume from a large sensor group is creating bottlenecks for real-time data processing and transmission through a limited wireless spectrum. To alleviate these problems, the SWiT-IoT research project investigated a two-phase approach. On the first phase, the project investigated a local processing or computational unit for in-situ low-level signal processing, data reduction, and enable high volume of data communication within the specified bandwidth. On the second phase, the project investigated a novel pulse-encoding scheme using orthogonal analog pulses to compress the data volume further.

As a part of the local processing unit, the project demonstrated the design and simulation of a modified Oscillatory Neural Network (ONN) for hierarchical pattern storage and classification, network based computation and local fault detection, and spatial-spectral analysis for bridge health monitoring. A weakly coupled phase oscillator model is analyzed in the case of both linear and nonlinear couplings, where convergence time and frequency of synchronization are considered as the indicators of recognition. An array of sensors is considered for structural health monitoring and the sensor outputs affect the coupling weights of the ONN. The beauty of ONN structure is, it can store a pattern (i.e. sensor output) through the coupling weights and exhibits a synchronized output for a close-in-match input pattern or sensor data. Any predefined deviation of sensor outputs results in desynchrony in ONN and indicates the anomaly in structural health. The inherent computational power in ONN obviates the power-hungry digital processor and facilitates data reduction and reduced computational burden for the central data center. In this project, a Kuramoto model-based ONN consisting of 10 oscillating nodes was designed and simulated. An array of 10 strain sensors was considered to affect the coupling weights of the oscillating nodes and demonstrate network-level computation. The project also studied the associative memory model of the hierarchical oscillatory neural network. By utilizing a nonlinear coupling function and proper selection of specific coefficients, a stable 2-cluster was achieved for a sensing application. The hierarchical clustering dramatically reduces the time complexity by increasing the space complexity through multi-layer processing. The SWiT-IoT project also explored the analog-level design of an oscillatory neural network for in situ pattern recognition, resulting in significantly reduced computational loads at the processor and minimized data transfer. A series of 36 ring oscillators were coupled serially, and the network performed computations by synchronization. The coupling weights were modulated by sensor inputs which affected the stored memory by indicating the synchronization time and frequency of the network. The work studied the effects of synchronization time and frequency of the ONN for different supply voltages, coupling weights, and the number of oscillating nodes. The 36 oscillator ring neural network scheme was designed and simulated using the 130 nm SiGe BiCMOS process. Simulation results showed power consumption to be less than 5.6 mW for the entire ONN and pattern recognition based on synchronization frequency and 10s of ns time differences between the training and input patterns. Finally, an inkjet-printed nonlinear element was also investigated as an initiative for the future development of a machine learning platform on a flexible substrate.

For spectrum-efficient high-density data telemetry, the project investigated modified Hermitian polynomial-based analog orthogonal pulses and analog pulse based data encoding. The innovative pulse-sequence-based encoding increased the data volume (n-1)!-times by supporting n!- numbers of channels while sharing the same frequency spectrum. The research investigations in this project resulted in several new schemes, including multi-bit encoding using single order pulse, the pulse randomization scheme for low-level physical layer security, simplifying the pulse decoding algorithm using the gold-sequence concept, and spectrum sensing for short-range wireless telemetry. In this project, a novel channel encoding scheme was developed where, unlike a single pulse, a pulse sequence modulates the individual data channel. Using the permutation technique, the proposed method uses multi-order orthogonal pulses to create distinct pulse sequences. All the pulses are orthogonal and can coexist in the same time window; therefore superimposed on top of one another to create the composite signal representing compressed data volume. The cyclic pulse elimination is proposed using the correlation peak analysis to decode individual pulses from the combined signal. A MATLAB/Simulink platform was used to generate and embed the analog orthogonal pulses on a smaller footprint microcontroller. A prototype test platform was developed using commercially available customized RF modules to validate the feasibility and compatibility of analog pulse transmission using the existing communication architecture and network protocol.

The project generated 49 research articles in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings. The project outcomes generated collaborations. Two PhD students and five Master's students have already graduated. Two more PhD students are expected to graduate by Fall 2022. Through supplemental funding, the project also supported two REU students, 15 undergraduate student design projects, and summer camp activities.
